  • Description: As a result of a forklift puncture, a 55-steel drum containing Methanol was punctured. This resulted in 15-gallons of Methanol released onto a concrete, dock floor affecting a 10'x10' area. A Contractor was called to clean-up the spill. The damaged drum was over-packed into a 95DF along with absorbent pads and booms. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted.

item.title: Report E-2024010517
item.description:
Report E-2024010517

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T15:12:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-29
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LDA experienced a UN3264 ARSURF 9590 SURFACTANT release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 40-gallons of product released to a 10’ x 10’ area of the concrete dock floor as well as a 2’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a container failure. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents and Color Safe for Acids neutralizer were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to clean the release. All impacted absorbents and PPE were then containerized into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: GALLIPOLIS FERRY
  • State: WV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 24, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1993 was damaged due to unknown causes and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews transferred the remaining product from the damaged tote into a new 330-gallon poly tote and readied for continued shipping. FCE deployed absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and swept them in with hand tools. All cleanup waste was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The empty/damaged tote and the waste drum were staged onsite for disposal.

  • Description: On January 24, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN2922 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately 120-gallons of product to the trailer interior, pavement below the trailer, and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Hazmat Services, Inc. (EHS) to remediate the impacted site. EHS personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizing agent to remediate the site. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into six (6) 55-gallon drums. Crews transferred the remaining product in the damaged 275-gallon tote into one (1) 275 gallon tote. All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010520
item.description:
Report E-2024010520

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T15:12:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-25
  • City: Brewster
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wheeling and Lake Erei Railway
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: I, John Vergis Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE, was called by the WLE Brewster Yardmaster at 0130 hrs. on 1-25-2024 for a report of leaking tank car GATZX 80031. When I arrived to look at the car, I noticed that the car was leaking from the breadbox cover. I removed seal #0000823 and opened the lid to find that the leak was coming from the Apollo Liquid Valve. I saw that the valve stem nut was backed off the stem and that the valve handle was not secured tight to the stem anymore. It looked like when someone tried to tighten the valve, that is did not close all the way because the valve handle did not fit properly since it was loose. I applied the handle back on the stem and tried closing the valve. The valve did then close and the leak stopped. The liquid was leaking from out of the valve plug which was not tight. I tried to tighten the valve stem nut but I could not get it to tighten. I backed off the nut completely and found that someone tried installing a course thread nut onto a fine thread valve stem. That is why the nut would not tighten down onto the handle. I then tried installing a fine thread nut and I was able to get it to tighten down. I felt that is was a good fix. I then removed the plug from the valve since it was leaking and found that there was no thread tape on the threads that were screwed into the valve. There was a build up of old tape on the top portion of the threads but not on the threads that would actually seal. Installed new thread sealant and tightened the valve plug. I then closed the breadbox lid and inatalled new seal #0000229. I then released the car for transportation.

One (1) 55-gallon drum that contained the one (1) damaged 5-gallon jug and spent absorbent pads was generated as waste and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

ER personnel deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools, utilizing a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. All paint impacted material was collected and containerized for disposal by R+L.

item.description:
Report E-2024010469

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-22
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 22, 2024, one (1) 500-pound cylinder of UN1009 was hissing when moved and covered in ice. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to inspect the cylinder and remediate the site. TLE personnel inspected the cylinder for any punctures or damage. No damage was found. Crews observed the cylinder was off gassing, creating a reaction. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, and absorbent pads, to remove ice from the frozen cylinder. Crews then moved the cylinder to the OS&D heat room, so the cylinder could gently warm up, and continue to release all of its contents. TLE personnel verified the cylinder released all of its contents and finished off gassing. Crews estimated 186 pounds of gas released. TLE personnel recommended the cylinder warm up a few hours before sending it for continued processing and shipping. All Ansul Halon 1301 (UN1009) impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 5-gallon pail and R+L personnel took possession of the waste to be added to the facility waste stream.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Hazmat Services, Inc. (EHS) to remediate the impacted site. item.title: Report E-2024010458
item.description:
Report E-2024010458

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-18
  • City: ROCK RIVER
  • State: WY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 18, 2024, at 0200 EST, an XPO Logistics tractor trailer hauling double trailers (truck # 05328716, trailer #s 03171129, 03171874) was involved in a rollover accident due to inclement weather conditions. Immediately after the accident occurred, the roads to the site were closed due to the weather and the unit was left onsite. No drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release. On January 18, 2024, at 0256 EST, XPO Logistics contacted Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) to manage and oversee the above referenced incident. ERTS secured Haz-Mat Response Inc. (HMRI) to perform emergency response and remediation. On January 18, 2024, HMRI responded to the site at 1140 ET to obtain an assessment of the site. At the time, there was no visual release of material from the unit, but it was also in 5-6” of snow. Once HMRI left site, the wrecker unit showed up at approximately 1300 ET to haul the unit offsite. Initially they did not report seeing a release of material when the unit was up righted. On January 19th, HMRI mobilized to the wrecker yard to find the batteries had released approximately 50-100 gallons of battery acid to the trailer floor, walls, ceiling, and soil along the passenger side of the unit in the wrecker yard. An estimated 5-gallons of acid impacted a 26’ x 1’ area of the soil in the dirt lot. Soda ash and floor dry were deployed to the impacted trailer floor to neutralize the acid. The wrecker crew then advise to HMRI there was a loss of acid to the incident site in the soil median where the unit came to a rest. HMRI secured the unit at the wrecker’s yard and mobilized to the accident site where they confirmed an approximate 2-gallon release to a 5’ x 15’ area of the median ditch. The area was hand excavated and all impacted soil placed into a drum which was removed from site. At this point, the 7-gallons of material confirmed to impact soil/dirt was reported to the WY DEQ. On January 22, 2024, at 1100 ET, HMRI returned to the wrecker yard to complete trailer remediation. Each battery was wiped down and inspected. All 70 salvageable batteries were secured on the unit on 4 pallets to be hauled back to XPO with the unit. The trailer floor was neutralized with soda ash and floor dry, and the soil was hand excavated. A total of 213 damaged batteries were containerized into (9) 95-gallon poly drums and will attempt to be recycled. All impacted debris including the impacted floor dry, soda ash, soil, dirt, poly sheeting, cardboard, and PPE were collected and containerized into (2) 55-gallon poly and (3) 95-gallon poly drums for disposal. All waste is currently located at HMRI’s shop located in Windsor, CO pending profiling, disposal, and recycling. Please see attached photos (Appendix 2).

  • Description: The driver was traveling on I-71WB in KY when a passer by flagged him down. He then pulled off at the Sulfur Ky exit and inspected his load he noticed a frozen material at the back door of the trailer. The driver then grabbed some absorbent to put down at the back of the trailer to prevent material from getting on the ground. The driver then called our emergency line at 1351ET to report the incident. The team was dispatched and arrived at 1745ET to start the clean up. The team dawned the proper PPE and proceeded to clean up the frozen material at the back of the trailer. There was aprxemetly 1-2oz that made it to the ground everything else was contained to the trailer and absorbent wags. Once that was cleaned they opened the trailer and found material frozen on the floor and proceeded to clean it up. They then gained access to the drum that was about half way in the trailer and found that the bottom of the drum has approximately 1in crack at the bottom. The team put the damaged container into a salvage drum along with absorbents used to clean up the material. The team was able to finish the clean up around 0100ET.

item.description:
Report X-2024010515

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-29T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-11
  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KY AN AIR PACKAGE WET FROM RAINWATER WAS BEING REWRAPPED WHEN AN INNER BOX WAS FOUND WITH A UN3481 LITHIUM BATTERY MARK. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION OF THE INNER CONTENTS DISCOVERED THREE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES CONTAINED IN EQUIPMENT. THERE IS ONE HP OFFICE JET 200 MOBILE PRINTER WITH A UN3481 LABEL ON THE CONSUMER PACKAGING. THERE IS A LITHIUM-ION BATTERY PACK ATTACHED TO THE PRINTER, MODEL NUMBER CZ993-60017. THERE IS ANOTHER BOX INSIDE THE PACKAGE THAT CONTAINS ONE PANASONIC TOUGHBOOK WITH TWO ATTACHED LITHIUM-ION BATTERY PACKS, MODEL NUMBER FZ-VSU1HU. THERE ARE ALSO ADDITIONAL NON-DANGEROUS GOODS ITEMS INSIDE THE PACKAGE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES CONTAINED IN EQUIPMENT PRODUCTS WERE BEING SHIPPED IN THE AIR NETWORK. PRIOR TO DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM ATL TO SDF.

  • City: FARMINGVILLE

  • Description: RESPONDED TO A PACKAGE THAT WAS COLD TO THE TOUCH. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY ONE POUND OF DRY ICE PELLETS COOLING TWO HIV RAPID CONTROL PACKS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED AIR SERVICE. OUTER BOX HAS A GREEN STICKER APPLIED "REFRIGERATE CONTROLS UPON ARRIVAL". THE BOX IS A ULINE INSULATED SHIPPER BOX PREPRINTED RUSH AND PERISHABLE WITH ORIENTATION UP ARROWS. A PACKING LIST IS IN A POUCH ON THE SIDE OF THE BOX AND DOES INDICATE THE CONTENTS HIV RAPID CONTROL PACK AND "SHIP WITH DRY ICE AND STORE AT 2-8 C UPON ARRIVAL". DUE TO THE FOLDING PATTERN THE DRY ICE INFORMATION SHOWING UNDER THE STORAGE COLUMN ON THE PACKING LIST WAS NOT VISIBLE. THE PACKAGE WAS SCANNED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER FOR FLIGHT BUT WAS NOT FLOWN.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-24
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCO experienced a UN3264 Kroff KR-B3020 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 20’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Sodium bicarb and absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean and neutralize the release. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were then collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized into an 85-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023120219
item.description:
Report E-2023120219

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T00:33:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-22
  • City: LIVINGSTON
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 11/22/2023, at approximately 13:51 hours, CSX train M54121 derailed at milepost 00C 138.8. As a result of the derailment two tank cars containing sulfur breached and released their contents which caught fire. Additionally, an empty tank car, which last contained methanol, was determined to have breached. Multiple other rail cars containing non-regulated materials also breached and released contents- some of which caught fire. The shippers of hazardous materials (loaded and residue shipments) were notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2023-11-22-00172). Multiple response contractors, as well as CSX Hazardous Materials Team personnel, were responded to the incident emergently. CSX and contractor personnel contained the fire and releases, as well as remediated the environmental impact. Due to air quality concerns from the fire, local responders recommended that residents in the area of the derailment site evacuate. This recommended evacuation applied to a single residence shortly after the derailment occurred and continued to expand for several hours until it included the entire town of Livingston, KY. On 11/23/2023, at 16:00 hours, response officials lifted the evacuation.
